t: Song of Solomon 2
I*pn am a wildflower of Sharon, a*ln lily of the valleys.
Man
Like*pn a lily among thorns, so*ln is my darling among the young women.
Woman
Like*pn an apricot tree among the trees of the forest, so*ln is my love among the young men. I*ln delight to sit in his shade, and*ln his fruit is sweet to my taste.
He*ln brought me to the banquet hall, and*ln he looked on me with love.
Sustain*ln me with raisins; refresh*ln me with apricots, for*ln I am lovesick.
May*ln his left hand be under my head, and*ln his right arm embrace me.
Young*ln women of Jerusalem, I charge you by*ln the gazelles and the wild does of the field, do*ln not stir up or awaken love until*ln the appropriate time.
Listen!*pn My love is approaching. Look!*ln Here he comes, leaping*ln over the mountains, bounding*ln over the hills.
My*ln love is like a gazelle or*ln a young stag. See,*ln he is standing behind our wall, gazing*ln through the windows, peering*ln through the lattice.
My*ln love calls to me:
Man
Arise,*pn my darling. Come*ln away, my beautiful one.
For*ln now the winter is past; the*ln rain has ended and gone away.
The*ln blossoms appear in the countryside. The*ln time of singing has come, and*ln the turtledove’s cooing is heard in our land.
The*ln fig tree ripens its figs; the*ln blossoming vines give off their fragrance. Arise,*ln my darling. Come*ln away, my beautiful one.
My*pn dove, in the clefts of the rock, in*ln the crevices of the cliff, let*ln me see your face, let*ln me hear your voice; for*ln your voice is sweet, and*ln your face is lovely.
Woman
Catch*pn the foxes for us— the*ln little foxes that ruin the vineyards — for*ln our vineyards are in bloom.
Woman
My*pn love is mine and I am his; he*ln feeds among the lilies.
Until*ln the day breaks and*ln the shadows flee, turn*ln around, my love, and be like a gazelle or*ln a young stag on the divided mountains.
